'''Angela Masson''' was the first woman to be [[Type rating|type-rated]] on the [[Boeing 747]] on June 30, 1984.<ref name="isa">{{cite news|title=ISA FIRSTS by Aircraft |url=http://www.iswap.org/FirstsAircraft.html |publisher=International Society of Women Airline Pilots |accessdate=2006-12-15 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061124191452/http://www.iswap.org/FirstsAircraft.html |archivedate=2006-11-24 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
==Flying career== Masson began flying lessons at age 15 at [[Clover Field]] in [[Santa Monica, California]]. Shortly after getting her pilot's license, she started [[air racing]]. At age 21, while flying in the [[Powder Puff Derby (1947)|Powder Puff Derby]], she set a record as the youngest person to fly coast to coast in a high performance aircraft.<ref name="ReferenceA">Int'l Women Pilots: 99 News, July 2000</ref>
In 1971 she trained armed forces pilot cadets at fellow aviatrix [[Claire Walters Flight School]] to build her flight experience, getting over 1,000 flight hours in less than a year. She then went on to fly as a charter pilot for [[Express Airways]] out of [[Naval Air Station Lemoore]] on a civilian contract for the Navy. Frustrated to see her former male students flying jets while females were barred from the military, she went back to school. At age 24, she wrote her PhD dissertation "Elements of Organizational Discrimination: The Air Force Response to Women as Military Pilots,"<ref name="Chicago Tribune">{{cite web |first=Patty |last=Shillington |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1995-10-29/travel/9510290155_1_pilot-military-academies-lofty-life |title=High Flier |publisher=Chicago Tribune |date=1995-10-29}}</ref> which was presented before Congress during the Hearings about opening military the Academies to women (a copy can be found in the Congressional Records). Her paper was read by [[Robert Crandall]], then President of [[American Airlines]], who hired her as a pilot for American in 1976, at age 25.<ref name="Chicago Tribune" /> During her career there, she was the first woman to fly as First Officer on the [[Boeing 707]], [[Boeing 767|767]] and [[Douglas DC-10]].<ref name="ReferenceA" />
Masson earned aircraft type-ratings on the [[Airbus A310]], Boeing 747, [[Boeing 757|757]], [[Boeing 767|767]], [[Boeing 777|777]], [[Douglas DC-9|DC-9]], [[DC-10]], and [[MD-11]]. She holds the ATP license with commercial glider and seaplane endorsements, as well as flight engineer, ground and flight instructor certificates.
Flying as Captain for over 20 years, she was the first female Chief Pilot for [[American Airlines]] (Miami domicile, 1997). As the most senior female pilot, she retired with over 31 years total service in December 2007.
==Academic career== Dr. Masson graduated from Collegio Monte Rosa in [[Territet, Switzerland]] and got her BFA, MA, MPA and PhD in Public Administration from the [[University of Southern California]]. The Federation Aeronautique Internationale lists Dr. Masson's numerous Commercial Air Route Speed Awards set in the [[Boeing 777]].<ref name="fai">{{cite news|title=History of Aviation and Space World Records |url=http://records.fai.org/pilot.asp?from=ga&id=3767 |publisher=Fédération Aéronautique Internationale (FAI) |accessdate=2006-12-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060512101446/http://records.fai.org/pilot.asp?from=ga&id=3767 |archivedate=2006-05-12 }}</ref>
==Art== A gifted artist, she was honored in art shows in Italy at the age of 18.<ref>"L'americana Masson espone all'Estense," ''Gazzetta di Ferrara'', Ferrara, Italy, July 10, 1969; "Galleria – Sensibilita della Masson," ''il Resto del Carlino'', Bologna, Italy, July 13, 1969; "Angela," ''Il Nuovo Veneto'',Venezia, Italy, September 1, 1969; "Angela Masson," ''La Vernice , Periodico di Attualtia Culturale Arte'', Venezia, Italy, August,1969; "Cronache Verona," ''L'Arena di Verona'', Verona, Italy, August 12, 1969; "Pittura 'paism' di Angela alla galleria 'Il salotto'," ''Il Gazzettino'', Edizione Nationale, Italy, August 7, 1969; "Al 'Salotto' espone pittrice italiana d'America," ''La Notte'', Milano, Italy, August 7, 1969</ref><ref>Italian exhibits: "stati d'animo" Galleria d'Arte Estense; Ferrara, Italy 7–19 July 1969; "stati d'anino" Galleria Il Triglione; Venezia, Italy 19–30 July 1969; "Paism" Galleria Il Salotto; Verona, Italy 1–13 August 1969</ref> She also sang: under the stage name "Tangela Tricoli" she recorded an album in 1982, "Jet Lady," which was re-released in 2004 by ArfArf records.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Jet-Lady-Tangela-Tricoli/dp/B0002BK9KI|title=Amazon.com: Jet Lady: Tangela Tricoli: Music:|accessdate=21 September 2011}}</ref> She briefly hosted ''The Tangela Tricoli Talk Show'' on public access TV in Los Angeles.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NNV82_iWjPo</ref>
==Patents==
The first true [[electronic flight bag]], a computing device designed specifically to replace a pilot’s entire kit bag, was patented by Masson as the Electronic Kit Bag (EKB) in 1999.<ref>USPTO Patents [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=1&p=1&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&S1=%28masson.INNM.+AND+angela%29&OS=in/masson+AND+angela&RS=%28IN/masson+AND+angela%29 # 17,974,775] Masson; Angela Electronic kit bag; and, [http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-adv.htm&r=2&p=1&f=G&l=50&d=PTXT&S1=(masson.INNM.+AND+angela)&OS=in/masson+AND+angela&RS=(IN/masson+AND+angela) # 27,970,531] Masson; Angela Electronic kit bag</ref> Her multiple patents describe a solution to aid pilots in their normal aviation activities, however, the EKB is intended to also function as a life-saving control device, able to land an aircraft remotely in the event of pilot incapacitation.
